channel.title: Sddc on SDN-Warrior | Daniel Krieger
channel.description: Recent content in Sddc on SDN-Warrior | Daniel Krieger

item.title: VCF9 BUG: After deleting a VCF instance on VCF Operations, no VCF instance can be imported anymore
item.description:
Introduction

While preparing for an article that has not yet been published, I ran into an interesting VCF bug. For the article, I had to delete a VCF instance from my operations. For background information, I currently have three VCF instances onboarded in my fleet. Since I had to reinstall one of them, I removed it according to the official instructions, and that’s when the problems started.

Disclaimer

Warning
I have reported the error to Broadcom, but as of now (December 3, 2025), the error and the solution have not been confirmed or acknowledged. I can reproduce and resolve the error multiple times, but I must reiterate that you do so at your own risk.

Error pattern and impact

At first glance, the VCF instance can be deleted normally and everything appears to be functioning correctly. The error only becomes apparent when the vCLM (aka Fleet Manager) is required and the old VCF instance has been deleted. Typical errors:

item.title: VCF9 - VCF5.X to VCF9 upgrade
item.description:
Introduction

I have been asked several times on LinkedIn for an article on the topic of brownfield upgrades from VCF 5 to VCF 9. Well, here we are. I thought it would be relatively easy and that you could just click your way through, but I was wrong. But let’s start at the beginning.

As things stand at the moment, if you have NSX version newer then 4.2.1.3 in your VCF environment, here’s the bad newsâ€”it’s not possible as of today. NSX 4.2.1.4 and newer has a newer code base than NSX 9.0.0.0 and is therefore not compatible. The problem should be fixed with VCF 9.0.1.

item.title: VCF - How to use the Broadcom Download Token
item.description:
Introduction

Broadcom is currently changing the access to their public repo. This affects many products. Affected are vCenter, ESXi Updates, vSAN File Services and of course VCF. The changes are far-reaching. The repo URL has changed and also the way it can be accessed. With the username and password of the Broadcom account, access will no longer work from April 23, 2025. Time to take a look at the whole thing.
